I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  From  2003  to  2007,  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  implemented  a  policy  
research-oriented regional technical assistance (RETA) entitled Making Markets Work Better for 
the Poor (M4P1), which covered Viet Nam, Lao People’s Democratic Republic, and Cambodia. 
This $2.4 million RETA was cofinanced by ADB, the Department for International Development 
(DFID)  of  the  United  Kingdom,  and  the  Asian  Development  Bank  Institute.  During 
implementation,  additional  cofinancing  was  obtained  from  AusAID  and  the  ADB  Poverty 
Reduction Fund, bringing the RETA’s total to $2.9 million. The RETA also entered into joint 
funding arrangements with the Mekong Private Sector Development Facility, and Centre de 
Coopération Internationale en Recherche Agronomique pour le Développement (CIRAD). M4P1 
was successful in raising awareness of the potentially positive role of market development in 
achieving poverty reduction as well as economic growth1 and was completed at the end of 2007. 
The  knowledge  generated  was  disseminated  widely  to  the  public  and  discussed  with 
government  agencies and  other  stakeholders.  At  the  December  2006  Advisory  Committee 
Meeting for the RETA, DFID expressed an interest in cofinancing Making Markets Work Better 
for the Poor Phase 2 (M4P2).  
 
2.  A TA reconnaissance mission, with participation from DFID, was fielded in Hanoi, Viet 
Nam, 23–25 January 2007 to assess the case for this follow-on phase. A memorandum of 
understanding signed on 11 July 2007 records the mutual understanding and agreements 
between the mission and the Government, and incorporates the main elements of the design 
and monitoring framework as shown in Appendix 1.2
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  The country strategy and program for Viet Nam3 supports the implementation of the Viet 
Nam Socioeconomic Development Plan (SEDP) and its target of reducing poverty incidence to 
10%–11% by the end of 2010. To achieve this goal, the poor must move to more productive 
occupations. Greater market participation by the poor is key to ensuring that the benefits of 
rapid growth remain equitably spread among all the population. The private sector is the main 
force behind this process as enterprises respond to opportunities presented by international and 
domestic  economic  integration,  which  generate  jobs  and  wealth.  Business-led  pro-poor 
economic growth is a focus of the Country Strategy and Program, and M4P2 will contribute 
directly to this objective through the generation of practical, replicable examples of market 
development combining the private sector’s resources and dynamism with the poor’s increasing 
participation. To help improve the impact and effectiveness of the ADB portfolio, some of these 
Making  Markets  Work  Better  for  the  Poor  (M4P)  examples  will  leverage  the  resources  of 
ongoing or planned ADB projects. By involving the private sector in the delivery of development 
objectives, M4P2 will complement other official development assistance activities based on the 
financing of government programs.  
 
4.  The  goal  of  M4P1  was  to  enhance  the  knowledge  and  understanding  of  the  links 
between growth and poverty and the dynamics of markets and institutions with a view to 
facilitating sustainable economic growth and poverty reduction. The outputs and purposes of 
M4P1 were to: (i) undertake policy related studies on pro-poor market related issues, and build 
                                                 
1  M4P1, in collaboration with a growing network of over 30 Vietnamese research entities, successfully produced 18 
substantive research reports, 19 discussion papers, 17 briefings, and 12 bulletins on the participation of the poor in 
a range of factor, commodity, and service markets. 
2  The TA first appeared in ADB Business Opportunities on 10 October 2007. 
3   ADB. 2006. Country Strategy and Program: Viet Nam 2007–2010. Manila.

2   
capacity  amongst  local  researchers;  (ii)  build  networks  between  the  project,  researchers, 
policymakers, international organizations and other stakeholders; and (iii) utilize the research 
results and developed networks in order to have a positive impact on policies and planning 
related to pro-poor market development.  
 
5.  M4P1 funded more than 20 major research activities by a total of 31 local organizations 
which involved analytical studies on priority issues linked to market development and their 
interactions for poverty reduction in the main thematic areas of (i) factor markets that are 
important to the poor; (ii) the participation of the poor in global value chains; and (iii) markets 
and service delivery. The research results and developed networks have been utilized by M4P1 
in the development of markets to promote sustainable pro-poor economic growth. Examples of 
impacts of research under M4P1 include (i) the development of a sustainable smallholder 
bamboo production sector supplying IKEA4 with materials for flooring, delivering additional 
benefits of over $1 million per year to poor households in two rural districts of Thanh Hoa 
province;  (ii)  the  development  of  two  IFAD  supported  market-based  investment  projects 
amounting to more than $60 million for improving livelihoods of around 200,000 rural poor in 
four provinces; (iii) the development of a legal framework and improved management system for 
small-scale  street  vendors  benefiting  thousands  of  poor  women  in  Hanoi  and  surrounding 
provinces; and (iv) contributing to the development of revisions to the Law on Cooperatives, 
allowing for alternative forms of collective action suitable for the poor and improved operation of 
more than 5,000 agricultural cooperatives with more than 200,000 members nationwide.  
 
6.  DFID  and  ADB  have  supported  an  extensive  stakeholder  consultation  process  to 
validate  these  perceptions  of  M4P’s  relevance  to  Viet  Nam’s  development  priorities.  The 
consultations  focused  on  partnerships  established  during  M4P15  and  strongly  supported 
M4P2’s further development and implementation, highlighting that M4P2 should have a more 
practical, action-oriented approach in order to build directly on the strong theoretical background 
and networks developed under M4P1. The stakeholders recommended a sharper focus in 
M4P2 than the more broadly based M4P1 which resulted in selection of three key focus areas, 
based on the knowledge accumulated in these areas under M4P1 and stakeholder interest. 
Besides the "policy action" research to be undertaken to adapt the knowledge gained from 
M4P1, a significant portion of M4P2 expenditure will be on a competitive Market Participation 
Challenge Fund which will serve to finance implementing practical applications of pro-poor 
market initiatives in the three focus areas. 
 
III.  THE PROPOSED TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
7.  M4P2  will  build  on  M4P1’s  successful  experiences  but  will  also  reflect  its  lessons 
learned. M4P2 will be a country-specific TA.  Management and implementation responsibilities 
will be passed to Vietnamese institutions with strategic oversight provided by a multi-agency 
management board. TA activities will be more action-oriented and restricted to three focus 
areas: (i) infrastructure services, (ii) value chain development, and (iii) labor markets. The 
                                                 
4  IKEA is a privately-held, international home products retailer that sells low-price merchandise, including furniture, 
accessories, bathrooms, and kitchens, at retail stores around the world. 
5  These  stakeholders  include:  the  Prime  Minister’s  Research  Commission;  Central  Institute  for  Economic 
Management (CIEM); Viet Nam Chamber of Commerce and Industry (VCCI); Ministry of Planning and Investment 
(MPI); Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development; Ministry of Labor, Invalids and Social Affairs (MOLISA); and 
Ministry of Finance (MOF), in addition to the 10 Vietnamese research institutes who participated in M4P1. Among 
donors,  consultations  included  the  World  Bank,  German  Development  Cooperation,  International  Fund  for 
Agricultural Development, United Nations Development Programme, Mekong Private Sector Development Facility, 
and  AusAID.  Nongovernmental  organization  consultations  included  Oxfam,  Compliance  Review  Panel, 
International Development Enterprises, SNV, and local business associations.

3
proposed TA will incorporate an innovative matching grant scheme, a challenge fund, which is 
specifically aimed at engaging the private sector. 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
8.  The impact of the proposed TA is increased participation of the poor in markets for 
infrastructure  services,  value  chains,  and  private  sector  employment.  The  outcome  of  the 
proposed  TA  is  to  achieve  wider  application  of  M4P  approach  through  replication, 
institutionalization, and capacity building. The proposed TA will work with selected government 
agencies concerned and the Viet Nam Market Participation Challenge Fund (VMPCF) grantees 
in the areas of infrastructure services, value chains, and job creation. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
9.  The proposed TA comprises two components: (i) a policy action research and plan, and 
(ii) the VMPCF. The policy action research and plan facilitates the adoption of market-oriented 
and  pro-poor  action  plans  by  selected  government  agencies,  ADB,  and  other  donors  that 
financed investment projects and programs. These plans can then be instantly adopted by 
policymakers  and  project  implementers.  To  ensure  strong  demand  and  a  clear  practical 
application for the research outputs, each research proposal will be sponsored by a government 
or private sector client who also has a clearly stated need or demand for the research work. The 
VMPCF component will provide complementary investment support on a competitive matching 
grant basis for private enterprises that propose innovative new business models to engage the 
poor on a replicable and sustainable basis. The VMPCF will initially focus on agro-processing 
linkages with the poor but will expand to other areas such as infrastructure services if the initial 
implementation experience is positive.6
 
10.  The key activities for implementing these components are related to (i) project and 
knowledge  management,  including  facilitating  procurement  and  project  implementation, 
monitoring and reporting, knowledge management, communication, and advocacy of findings 
from action plans and challenge fund projects; and (ii) capacity development, including direct 
assistance to project stakeholders, including researchers, project staff, government agencies, 
private sector firms, and the poor. The TA will facilitate the exchange and application of lessons 
across  the  various  market  development  interventions  within  Viet  Nam  and  abroad.  It  will 
continue to develop the successful M4P1 communication tools, including the project web site, 
bi-monthly bulletin, and discussion papers and briefings. Adequate provision will be made to 
ensure  that  executing  agency  (EA)  and  implementing  agency  (IA)  staff  and  other  project 
stakeholders can participate in global M4P learning events sponsored by ADB/DFID. Activities 
related to capacity development will include training, workshops, and seminars, and will target 
specific bottlenecks that are impeding implementation. Continuing capacity development will 
also occur in the various methodologies and approaches associated with M4P, including further 
dissemination and development of the Participatory Market Assessment Handbook and Value 
                                                 
6  Challenge funds are a way to allocate grants competitively to corporate entities to implement development-oriented 
projects that meet the challenge fund eligibility criteria. Funds are used to encourage commercially-focused 
stakeholders to make extra efforts to reach the poor or devise market-based solutions that would significantly 
benefit the poor. Challenge funds have been used successfully in the United Kingdom to engage the private sector 
in socially desirable projects such as urban regeneration. More recently, DFID has tested several challenge funds, 
e.g., the Financial Deepening Challenge Fund, Business Linkages Challenge Fund, Ghana Business Linkages 
Challenge Fund, and Africa Enterprise Challenge Fund. 
7  In addition to the research studies completed under M4P1, ADB has maintained a dialogue over the past year with 
the Exchange for Social Investment and the World Resources Institute, which are nonprofit organizations working 
on this issue.

4   
Chain Development Toolbook, strategies for engagement with the “Base of the Pyramid,”7 
measures of market competitiveness, and the use of public-private partnerships in infrastructure 
provision and other services to the poor. 
 
11.  To maintain momentum and continuity, M4P2 will continue with selected M4P1 thematic 
work. To achieve a more direct impact on the livelihoods of the poor, M4P2 will also engage 
directly with ongoing government- and donor-financed investment projects. General criteria for 
selecting a project intervention include the potential for pro-poor impact, potential contribution to 
government priorities through market development and poverty reduction, likely sustainability, 
potential  for  leverage  of  ongoing  or  future  investment  projects,  ease  of  management  and 
implementation, practicality of intervention, degree of direct participation by the poor, design and 
implementation, degree of innovation, and ability to record and replicate the interventions.  
  
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
12.  The total cost of the proposed TA is estimated at $10.1 million equivalent, of which (i) 
$400,000 will be financed by ADB’s TA funding program, (ii) $8 million equivalent, of which $3 
million equivalent is for the VPMCF grants, will be cofinanced on a grant basis in pounds 
sterling  by  the  DFID  and  administered  by  ADB,  and  (iii)  $1.7  million  equivalent  will  be 
contributed in-kind by the Government. The cofinancing arrangement between ADB and DFID is 
joint cofinancing. Detailed cost estimates are shown in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Reviewing, Monitoring, and Evaluation  
13.  Sufficient resources from ADB are allocated for project monitoring and implementing. A 
TA  administration  memorandum,  similar  to  a  project  administration  memorandum,  will  be 
formulated and submitted to all stakeholders including ADB, DFID, EA, and IAs. A joint midterm 
review of the M4P2 by all financing parties will be carried out 30 months after the TA’s inception 
to assess the extent to which the targeted outputs and outcomes are achieved. The main 
criteria for success will be evidence of actual changes in business practices and the increased 
involvement of the poor, resulting from the activities carried out in the TA. DFID has indicated 
that following a successful implementation of M4P2, another phase of the project may follow. 
The conditions and criteria for proceeding to Phase 3 will be jointly determined by ADB, DFID, 
and the technical M4P2 team during the project inception. 
 
E.  Implementation Arrangements 
14.  ADB will administer the overall TA in close consultation with the EA—MPI—and two IAs 
for the two project components. The Central Institute for Economic Management (CIEM) will be 
the IA for the policy action research and plan component. TA implementation will be guided by a 
management board chaired by a vice minister from the Ministry of Planning and Investment 
(MPI) and comprising the following members: ADB, DFID, Farmers’ Association, Ministry of 
Agriculture and Rural Development, MOF, Ministry of Natural Resources and Environment, 
State Bank of Viet Nam, trade unions, and Viet Nam Chamber of Commerce and Industry 
(VCCI).  The  board  will  meet  quarterly  during  the  first  year  and  then  twice  yearly  once 
implementation is proceeding smoothly. The board will have three broad functions: (i) approval 
of the M4P2 strategy; (ii) fiduciary oversight, including review of annual audit reports and the 
VMPCF’s  six  monthly  financial  statements;  and  (iii)  appointing  and  holding  executive 
management accountable, especially in terms of the overall progress and impact of the project. 
In performing these functions, the board will be supported by three consulting groups working at 
the Project Coordination Unit (PCU), Policy Action Research Unit (PARU), and the VMPCF.

5
Appendix  3  presents  the  division  of  labor  among  the  IAs  and  detailed  implementation 
arrangements. As part of project inception, detailed implementation manuals will be developed.  
 
15.  The proposed TA will be implemented over a period of 3 years, from February 2008 to 
January 2011. It will engage a total of 73 person-months for international specialists and 246 
person-months for national specialists. The consultants will report to a designated TA officer 
and work under the overall supervision of the management board. A total of 12 consultants, 
located  at  the  PCU,  PARU,  and  VMPCF  (providing  192  person-months  of inputs),  will  be 
engaged  on  a  consulting  firm  basis.  In  addition  to  the  firm-based  consultant  team,  9 
independent  consultants/resources  persons  (providing  67  person-months  of  inputs)  will  be 
engaged on an individual basis for the purpose of (i) continuing operational work carried out 
under  the  M4P1  PCU,  including  communication,  advocacy,  and  knowledge  management 
activities;  (ii)  supporting  the  TA  officer  in  formulating  TA  administration  memorandum;  (iii) 
deepening M4P2 links to ADB’s Viet Nam portfolio for direct use by ADB by applying M4P 
approaches to ADB pipeline project development; and (iv) conducting an independent midterm 
review of the project’s implementation with ADB and DFID staff. A majority of consultants will be 
recruited on a firm basis to ensure the best synergy of all project components and activities. The 
reasons for allowing some individual selection are to: (i) ensure a continuation and smooth 
handover between the interim team and the permanent team, (ii) ensure sufficient resources be 
allocated for monitoring and implementing the TA, (iii) allow more flexibility in timely recruiting of 
appropriate consultants as the ADB programming and project implementation schedule are 
regularly adjusted, and (iv) provide objective inputs to the midterm review. The outline terms of 
reference for both the firm-based and individual-based consultants are contained in Appendix 4, 
and detailed terms of reference are included in Supplementary Appendix 1. The consultants will 
be  recruited  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of  Consultants  (2007,  as 
amended from time to time). The interested consulting firms are required to submit full technical 
proposals. The selection method of the firm will be quality- and cost-based selection criteria with 
a 80:20 quality-cost ratio. The project coordinator, under close consultation with ADB and DFID, 
will  be  responsible  for  organizing  the  workshops.  Supplementary  Appendix  2  presents  an 
overview of the first year workplan and indicative division of labor among project IAs. 
 
16.  Equipment will be procured for use at the PCU and PARU, and for the fund management 
team who manages the VMPCF, using ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2007, as amended from 
time  to  time).  After  TA  completion,  the  equipment  will  be  disposed  of  as  follows:  (i)  the 
equipment used by the PCU to MPI, (ii) the equipment used by the PARU to CIEM, and (iii) the 
equipment used for the VMPCF implementation to MOF. An advance payment facility (APF) will 
be established for the TA’s implementation to allow advanced payments on regular and planned 
activities including VMPCF payments to the grantees and expenses for workshops, seminars, 
and conferences. Expenditures under APF will be liquidated using statements of expenditure 
procedure and satisfactory external audit reports. Supplementary Appendix 3 presents the APF 
agreement to be incorporated in the TA agreement. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S RECOMMENDATION AND DECISION  
17.   The President recommends that the Board approve ADB administering a portion of 
technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $8,000,000 to the Government of Viet Nam 
for Making Markets Work Better for the Poor Phase 2, to be financed on a grant basis by the 
Government of the United Kingdom. If the Board approves ADB administering the technical 
assistance, the President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, will approve ADB 
providing the balance of the technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $400,000, for 
Making Markets Work Better for the Poor Phase 2.

DIVISION OF LABOR AMONG PROJECT IMPLEMENTING AGENCIES 
 
1.  The implementing agencies, the Central Institute for Economic Management (CIEM) and 
the Ministry of Finance (MOF), will implement tasks in line with their institutional comparative 
advantages.  Other  agencies  will  be  engaged to  implement  specific research  or  to  receive 
capacity-strengthening  assistance.  For  example,  the  Ministry  of  Construction,  Ministry  of 
Agriculture and Rural Development, Ministry of Health, and provincial people’s committees are 
likely to be involved in public-private partnership development in small-town and rural water and 
sanitation; Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development and Institute of Policy and Strategy for 
Agriculture and Rural Development are likely to be involved in value chain development; and the 
Ministry of Labor, Invalids and Social Affairs and Institute of Labor Science and Social Affairs 
are likely to be involved in labor market development. The Viet Nam Chamber of Commerce 
and Industry (VCCI) will play a key role in mobilizing private sector participation in both the 
challenge fund and in the implementation of action research pilots such as infrastructure public-
private partnerships, value chains, and skill development. As in Making Markets Work Better for 
the Poor Phase 1 (M4P1), Making Markets Work Better for the Poor Phase 2 (M4P2) will 
collaborate with other donor programs operating in these areas. 
 
2.  CIEM will lead the management and commission of action research, ensuring relevance 
to Viet Nam’s development priorities, consistency with pro-poor market development and the 
project’s themes, and a strong demand from an implementing or operational agency. CIEM will 
ensure that the research has a strong action orientation and leads to the final product of an 
action plan. It will carefully monitor the delivery of outcomes and ensure that the main messages 
and lessons from the action research and implementation of the action plan are included in the 
M4P2 communication and advocacy strategy. It will assume the lead knowledge management 
role by facilitating the use and uptake of project learning by policymakers and implementers.  
 
3.  MOF  will  oversee  the  management  and  implementation  of  the  Viet  Nam  Market 
Participation Challenge Fund (VMPCF). The VMPCF’s direct daily operations will be contracted 
to an independent consulting firm as part of the overall firm-based consultant team. MOF will 
collaborate with VCCI to leverage the VCCI network of private sector enterprises and to ensure 
that the opportunities available under the VMPCF are well known by enterprises. VCCI will help 
identify potential private sector applicants and ensure that they have a strong understanding of 
the requirements and eligibility criteria. MOF will ensure that the development impact and 
replication  of  challenge  fund  models  are  effectively  monitored,  making  sure  that  the  main 
lessons learned are included in M4P2 knowledge management, communication, and advocacy 
activities. VCCI will facilitate private sector participation within the main project themes. For 
example, the success of public-private partnership arrangements for infrastructure delivery will 
depend on good private enterprise participation for effective service delivery. Similarly, private 
enterprises are the main drivers of value chain upgrading and are the main employers in labor 
markets. Monitoring and learning lessons from the operational experience of firms will provide 
useful information for policymakers. 
 
A.  Detailed Implementation Arrangements 
 
4.  The  following  paragraphs  further  elaborate  the  implementation  arrangements  to  be 
carried out in the three project units.  
 
5.  Project Coordination Unit. The Viet Nam Resident Mission of the Asian Development 
Bank (ADB) will host the central project coordination unit (PCU). The PCU will implement the 
two crosscutting project components, e.g., project and knowledge management and capacity

10  Appendix 3 
development,  to  ensure  linkage  and  synergy  between  action  research  and  challenge  fund 
components and scaling up M4P2 impact in Viet Nam and the region. The PCU will undertake 
the following tasks: (i) serve as the secretariat to the management board by organizing and 
facilitating the board meetings; (ii) monitor, report, and review project implementation; (iii) scale 
up M4P2 impact through knowledge management activities with other international development 
agencies; (iv) organize training, seminars, and workshops for knowledge dissemination and 
capacity-building purposes; and (v) carry out communication and advocacy activities. In addition 
to the firm-based consultant team, the PCU will host short-term, independent consultants who 
will be recruited on an individual basis to ensure complementary inputs to the implementation of 
ongoing government and ADB projects as well as to the formulation of ADB projects in the 
2007–2010  pipeline,  and  subjective  inputs  to  ADB  and  Department  for  International 
Development (DFID) staff for the midterm review of project implementation for considering the 
continuation of Phase 3. 
 
6.  Policy  Action  Research  Unit.  CIEM  will  host  and  implement  the  Policy  Action 
Research  Unit,  ensuring  the  relevance  of  M4P2  research  activities  to  the  needs  and 
requirements of government policymakers. The selection of the policy action research and plan 
proposals will follow the general criteria for selecting a project intervention as stated (see para. 
10 of the main text). These proposals will be endorsed by the management board as part of 
M4P2. CIEM will lead the management and commission of action research using a competitive 
selection process, ensuring relevance to Viet Nam’s development priorities, consistency with 
pro-poor  market  development  and  the  project’s  themes,  and  strong  demand  from  an 
implementing or operational agency. CIEM will ensure that the research has a strong action 
orientation and leads to the final product of an action plan. It will carefully monitor the delivery of 
outcomes and ensure that the main messages and lessons from the action research and 
implementation of the action plans are included in the M4P2 communication and advocacy 
strategy. CIEM will assume the lead knowledge management role by facilitating the use and 
uptake of project learning by policymakers and implementers.  
 
7.  Viet Nam Market Participation Challenge Fund. MOF will supervise the VMPCF’s 
management and operations. MOF will implement the VMPCF with assistance of the fund 
management team, which will be recruited as part of the firm-based consultant team. This team 
will responsible for the VMPCF’s day-to-day operations, including handling queries, marketing 
and communication, financial management, and monitoring and evaluation of the grantees. The 
team will receive guidance and direction from the management board while coordinating with an 
independent  assessment  panel.  In  view  of  the  VMPCF’s  private  sector  focus,  MOF  will 
cooperate with VCCI in order to make use of the VCCI countrywide private sector network to 
mobilize the participation of private sector players in the competitive selection process.  
 
8.  Nature of the VMPCF, Eligibility Criteria, and Disbursement.1 The VMPCF’s overall 
goal  is  to  leverage  private  sector  involvement  in  the  delivery  of  Viet  Nam’s  development 
objectives, including employment and better services to the poor. Grants will be given for 
innovative and eligible projects, and funding decisions will be made on a competitive, deadline-
driven basis by an independent panel. The most desirable bids will receive funding on a grant 
basis. Bidders are expected to contribute, at a minimum, 51% of total project costs in cash and 
in-kind, as defined in VMPCF guidance on bidder contributions. Eligible projects will qualify for 
funding if they can demonstrate that the project (i) contributes directly or indirectly to improved 
                                                 
1  VMPCF’s  detailed  recommended  nature  and  mechanisms  are  included  in  the  consultant  report  by  Coffey 
International Development Ltd. 2007. Viet Nam Market Participation Challenge Fund Site Visit Report. Manila in 
ADB. 2003. Technical Assistance for Making Markets Work Better for the Poor. Manila.

Appendix 3  11 
incomes and economic opportunities for poor people that have limited access to Viet Nam’s 
growing market economy, (ii) is commercially sustainable and increases the competitiveness 
and viability of the businesses involved after the VMPCF grant is utilized, (iii) is potentially 
replicable elsewhere in the country, (iv) demonstrates that it cannot obtain commercial finance 
or other sources of finance, (v) uses the fund provided by the VMPCF within 3 years except in 
exceptional circumstances, (vi) does not create permanent unfair competition, and (vii) does not 
cause any social or environmental damage. The VMPCF’s operational policies and procedures 
were prepared by challenge fund specialists under M4P1. These policies and procedures will be 
elaborated in an operations manual by the fund manager following the establishment of the 
management  board  but  prior  to  the  implementation  of  the  initial  VMPCF  bidding  round. 
Disbursement will be made quarterly in arrears upon the receipt of proof of expenditure as 
included in the contract letter between the VMPCF and the grantee. Such a contract letter will 
specify the drawdown, reporting, supervision, and review of the grantee’s project.

12  Appendix 4 
 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Firm-Based Recruitment1
1.  A consulting team of 3 international consultants (totaling 60 person-months of services) 
and 9 national consultants (totaling 192 person-months of services) will be recruited on a firm 
basis  using  quality-  and  cost-based  selection  criteria  with  a  80:20  quality-cost  ratio.  The 
consulting teams will be divided into three groups: (i) Project Coordination unit (PCU); (ii) Policy 
Action Research Unit (PARU); and (iii) Viet Nam Market Participation Challenge Fund (VMPCF). 
The hosts for the groups are the Viet Nam Resident Mission of the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB), Central Institution of Economic Management (CIEM), and the Ministry of Finance (MOF), 
respectively. The following section describes the consultants’ qualifications and general terms of 
references. Detailed responsibilities and tasks are included in Supplementary Appendix 1.  
 
1.  Project Coordination Unit (PCU) 
 
a.  Overall Project Coordination, Management, and Capacity Building  
 
i.  1 Project Coordinator (international, 30 person-months, full time), 
and 1 PCU Economist (national, 30 person-months, full time) 
 
2.  The  project  coordinator,  who  will  report  to  Ministry  of  Planning  and  Investment’s 
management board, will have postgraduate qualifications in development economics and/or a 
related discipline and at least 10 years of operational experience with market or private sector 
development. The consultant will also be familiar with poverty reduction and growth issues in 
Viet Nam.  
 
3.  The PCU economist will have a university degree in economics, possess excellent 
written and spoken English skills, and be well-versed in development policy issues in Viet Nam. 
The consultant will have at least 7 years of experience in development project implementation. 
The  consultant  will  work  closely  with  the  project  coordinator  and  relevant  staff  from  the 
executing agency (EA) and the implementing agencies (IAs).  
 
4.  The project coordinator and the PCU economist will work full time until the project’s 
implementation  is  complete.  The  consultants  will  carry  out  the  project’s  day-to-day 
implementation, covering administrative, organizational, and overall coordination, as well as 
provide  technical  inputs  when  required.  The  consultants  will  work  in  the  areas  of  (i) 
management  support;  (ii)  capacity  building  and  technical  advice;  and  (iii)  knowledge 
management, communication, and advocacy.  
 
b.  Knowledge Management 
   
i.  1 Knowledge Management Specialist (national, 30 person-months, 
full time) 
 
5.  The  knowledge  management  specialist  will  have  a  university  degree  in  economics, 
possess excellent written and spoken English skills, and be well-versed in development policy 
issues in Viet Nam. The consultant will have at least 5 years of experience in development 
project  implementation.  The  consultant  will  work  closely  with  the  project  coordinator  and 
                                                 
1 Financed by the Government of United Kingdom’s cofinancing funds.

Appendix 4  13 
relevant staff from the EA and IAs in undertaking tasks related to knowledge management and 
dissemination.  
 
c.  Communications and Advocacy 
   
i.  1 Communications and Advocacy Specialist (national, 30 person-
months, full time) 
 
6.  The communications and advocacy specialist will have a university degree in public 
relations or related areas and possess excellent written and spoken English skills. Working with 
other  members  of  the  Making  Markets  Work  Better  for  the  Poor  (M4P)  project  team,  the 
consultant  will  assist  with  activities  relating  to  communications,  publications,  web  site 
maintenance, and advocacy 
 
2.  Policy Action Research Unit (PARU) 
 
i.  1  Research  Action  Specialist  (international,  12  person-months, 
intermittent),  and  3  Thematic  Experts:  Labor  Markets/Public-
Private  Partnership/Value-Chains  (national,  totaling  36  person-
months, intermittent) 
 
7.  The research action specialist and the three thematic experts will be recruited to provide 
advisory support to CIEM in implementing the policy action research and plan component of the 
project covering the development of policy recommendations and actions related to M4P2’s 
three themes: (i) labor markets, (ii) public-private partnerships in infrastructure services, and (ii) 
value chains. The thematic experts will provide (i) inputs for selecting policy action research 
studies, and (ii) technical assistance (TA) to the IAs in the management and implementation of 
the M4P2 action research themes. The thematic experts will report to the research action 
specialist. Under the management board’s guidance and in close coordination with the PCU, the 
thematic  experts  will  assist  the  research  action  specialist  and  CIEM  in  the  day-to-day 
management  of  the  research  themes  and  the  ongoing  development  and  improvement  of 
activities undertaken under the research themes.  
 
3.  Viet Nam Market Participating Challenge Fund (VMPCF)  
 
a.  Fund Management Team (FMT) 
 
i.  1  Fund  Manager  (international, 18 person-months, intermittent), 1 
Project Manager (national, 30 person-months, full time), 1 Marketing 
and  Communications  Specialist  (national,  18  person-months, 
intermittent),  and  1  Financial  Management  and  Monitoring  and 
Evaluation Advisor (national, 18 person-months, intermittent) 
 
8.  The FMT will assist MOF and VCCI in establishing the main operational structures for 
the  challenge  fund  and  in  overseeing  the  VMPCF.  The  fund  manager  will  have  direct 
operational  experience  in  operating  a  challenge  fund  in  a  developing  country.  The  FMT, 
reporting to the lead IA officer at MOF, will be responsible for (i) establishing and maintaining 
the  necessary  management  systems  and  processes  for  the  VMPCF,  (ii)  marketing  and 
communications, (iii) management of the bidding process, and (iv) financial administration and 
monitoring and evaluation. The FMT, while operating with the objectivity and prudence normally

14  Appendix 4 
 
expected of a financial service provider, will also adapt its methodologies to the distinctive 
nature of challenge funds, in particular working as a facilitator of new and innovative ideas. 
 
B.  Individual-Based Recruitment2
9.  A  total  of  13  person-months  of  services  from  international  consultants  and  54  
person-months from national consultants will be recruited on an individual basis to provide 
outputs for following purposes: (i) operationalizing the interim PCU, (ii) supporting the TA officer 
in monitoring and reporting project implementation using TA administration memoranda, (iii) 
assisting ADB and DFID staff in conducting independent midterm review of the project, and (iv) 
deepening M4P2 links to ADB’s Viet Nam portfolio. The following paragraphs describe the 
consultants’ qualifications and general terms of references.  
 
1.  Interim PCU (prior to the fielding of the firm-based consulting team) 
 
a.   1  Interim  Project  Coordinator  (international,  3  person-months, 
intermittent) 
 
10.  The  interim  project  coordinator  will  be  responsible  for  continuing  interest  from  the 
Government and other stakeholders, including other development partners and the local and 
regional research and development community, in the M4P concept and approach.  
 
11.  The interim PCU will also be supported by two short-term administrative assistants in the 
total consulting service input who will be recruited based on arrangements satisfactory to ADB 
for engaging national consultants.   
 
2.  Implementation Monitoring and Reporting 
 
    a.   1 Implementation Monitoring Officer (national, 36 person-months) 
 
12.  The  implementation  monitoring  officer  will  have  a  university  degree  in  economics, 
possess excellent written and spoken English, and be well-versed in development policy issues, 
particularly those related to M4P in Viet Nam. The consultant will have at least 7 years of 
experience in development project implementation. The consultant will work closely with the 
ADB  TA  officer,  (interim)  project  coordinator,  and  relevant  EA/IA  staff  in  preparing  the 
monitoring of the project’s implementation in both policy action research and plan and VMPCF 
components.  
13.  The consultant will carry out the following tasks: 
(i)  provide administrative, organizational, and financial management support to the IAs; 
(ii)  compile information on project implementation, and create a systematic monitoring 
and reporting database; 
(iii)  provide input to the interim PCU and PCU for the development of periodic work plans 
and  budgets  for  the  project,  outlining  the  main  tasks  of  the  IAs  and  the 
implementation team;  
(iv)  help the interim PCU and PCU to monitor physical and financial progress against 
approved plans and budgets; 
(v)  facilitate  the  preparation  of  physical  and  financial  progress  reports  and  project 
administration memoranda as required by the ADB TA officer;

(vi)  help to prepare policy briefs, bulletins, website material, and other written information 
based on the project outcomes for dissemination and policy dialogue; and  
(vii)  perform any other related work as assigned by the ADB TA officer. 
 
3.  Independent Project Review 
 
a.  1 Project Reviewer (international, 1 person-month, intermittent) 
 
14.  The consultant will carry out the following tasks: 
(i)  conduct a desk review of the project’s implementation for M4P2 in consultation with 
ADB and DFID; 
(ii)  interview stakeholders on the project’s implementation; 
(iii)  assess the progress made on the performance indicators identified in the design and 
monitoring framework and the triggers for proceeding with Stage 2 of M4P2; 
(iv)  recommend measures for accelerating the progress to be achieved as targeted in 
the design and monitoring framework; and 
(v)  prepare  a  report  detailing  the  review’s  methodology,  results,  findings,  and 
recommendations. 
 
4.  Deepening M4P2 Links to ADB’s Viet Nam Portfolio 
 
a.  Total of 9 person-months for 3 international consultants; total of 18 
person-months for 3 national consultants 
 
15.  Based  on  terms  of  reference  defined  jointly  by  relevant  ADB  staff  and  the  project 
coordinator in consultation with other stakeholders, short-term consultants will be recruited on 
an individual basis to provide a total of 12 person-months from international consultants and 24 
person-months from national consultants. Their main task will be to deepen M4P2 links to 
ADB’s Viet Nam portfolio as indicated in the Country Strategy and Program, corresponding 
updates  and  country  portfolio  review  missions,  through  innovative  ways  to  apply  M4P2 
approaches to ADB pipeline project development.
